text:
I've been converting many of my old projects ("phoenixing them as @llorenz might say) to Python 3 and the very first question I'd ask is:

- Is Python 2 backwards compatibility required? 

If so, then you have a bit different of a challenge, and my primary suggestion is to make the code 2.7 and 3.4+ compatible. I've made great use of the [six](https://pypi.python.org/pypi/six) and [future](http://python-future.org/)  libraries to achieve this. The `future` library is especially useful since it has a [cheat sheet](http://python-future.org/compatible_idioms.html) of Python 2-3 compatible idioms when using future, and can point you in the right direction for `six`. 

If Python 2 compatibility is _not_ required - then you can save yourself a lot of effort, and I recommend going this direction with your programs if possible. 

So if you learned and write decent Python _2.7_ code, I've found that it isn't very difficult to transition to Python 3. I usually go about this by first checking out a Python 3 branch and creating the virtual environment:

    $ git branch -b python3
    $ virtualenv -p python3 venvpy3
    $ source venvpy3/bin/activate 
    (venvpy3) $ pip install -r requirements.txt

This is a great first start because you'll discover that many of your direct dependencies have fewer sub-dependencies or may have different versions. It will also tell you if any module you use is not Python 3 compatible (though I've never encountered this). 

From there I simply run my tests and scripts and locate errors. The most common stuff for me are the following global replacements:

- `print` → `print()` 
- `xrange` → `range`
- `iteritems` → `items`
- `basestring` → `str` 
- `u""` → `""` 
- `hashlib.sha1(text)` → `hashlib.sha1(text.encode('utf-8'))` 
- `from cStringIO import StringIO` → `from io import StringIO` 
- `float(num) / float(div)` → `num / div` 

Many other errors are pretty easily Googleable via "Python 3 [ERROR MESSAGE]". 

Some other common gotchas include:

- Imports 
- Dictionary comprehensions 
- Strings and bytes 
- New style class extension 

The one that really bugs me is the `version` argument in `argparse`, but that's just one of the minor trivialities you have to deal with. 

For the most part, I've converted many of my old projects in just a few hours!

text:
I had a couple of other feature ideas, so I figured I'd add them to this thread. 

The first is the ability to subscribe to questions, threads, tags, and perhaps even profiles that you are interested in. Once subscribed, you would receive a notification (or perhaps daily digest) of the activity that has occurred in the things you've subscribed to. 

The second, is the ability for users to send messages to each other. I haven't fully thought through all the implications of implementing something this, so I'd be curious hear what others think about this and to discuss the upsides and downsides of having this as a feature. For example, would it make for a better online community experience if we allowed messaging, or would it be best to constrain all communications on the platform through the Q&A?  Thoughts?

text:
I was really excited about [Aardvark](https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/aardvark#/entity) before they got bought by Google a few years ago and were never heard from again, and I think that copying some of their features could help differentiate Minimum Entropy. They had a social search + question & answer service that was outstanding. 

If I remember correctly, when someone asked a question, it got routed to people that were qualified to answer it based on info they had provided in their profile (I think you chose a bunch of topics you were knowledgeable about at sign-up). If they didn't know the answer, they could forward you along to someone in their network that they thought could answer it (perhaps via email). It was kind of like the [small-world experiment](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Small-world_experiment) approach to question answering. I thought it was a clever way to both get quality answers to questions and also to grow the network of knowledgeable people on the service quickly. 

I only have a vague recollection of how everything worked because they were so good that they were only around for a hot second before they got acquired, but the features were genuinely useful and I haven't found anything else as good as what they had since. Does anyone else remember them?
